symptoms: you may also experience a mild headache, body aches or a low grade fever. typically, a cold lasts 2-14 days.

flu symptoms come on very quickly and can include: a sudden high temperature, an aching body, feeling tired or exhausted, a dry cough, a sore throat, a headache, difficulty sleeping, loss of appetite, diarrhea or tummy pain, feeling sick and being sick
response: You may have the flu. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: conjunctivitis, an inflammation of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines your eyelids and part of your eyeballs, has several possible causes it could be a bacterial or viral infection, an allergic reaction to pollen or animal dander, or a result of chemical irritants (smoke, chlorine, lens solution, etc.).

these symptoms may last a few hours to several weeks: redness, itching, tearing, burning sensation, pus-like discharge and/or crusting of the eyelids. because conjunctivitis causes inflammation of the small blood vessels in the conjunctiva to become more prominent, the whites of your eyes will appear pink or red. When you wake you are likely to feel that your eyelids are pasted shut, and your vision may not be as clear as usual.
response: You may have conjunctivitis. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: cramping or pain in the abdomen
possibly fever or bloody stools, depending on the cause
pain in the tum, cramps, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. you may also have a fever and bloody stools, depending on the cause.
bacterial infection, caused by contaminated food or water
parasites, which can enter the body through food or water
food intolerance, such as the inability to digest lactose, the sugar in milk
medication, such as some antibiotics or antacids containing magnesium
response: You may have diarrhea. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: the main symptom of acute pancreatitis is a severe, dull pain around the top of your stomach that develops suddenly
the pain may spread to your back and become worse after eating
the pain may be so severe that you can't sit still
you may also have a fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, indigestion, and jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
tenderness or swelling of the abdomen (tummy)
response: You may have acute pancreatitis. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: worsening of asthma or eczema symptoms
symptoms of an allergic reaction usually develop within a few minutes of being exposed to something you're allergic to, although occasionally they can develop gradually over a few hours
response: You may have allergies. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: forget about recent conversations or events, or misplace items
forget the names of places and objects, or have trouble thinking of the right word
repeat themselves regularly, such as asking the same question several times
show poor judgement or find it harder to make decisions
become less flexible and more hesitant to try new things
increasing confusion and disorientation – for example, getting lost, or wandering and not knowing what time of day it is
delusions (believing things that are untrue) or feeling paranoid and suspicious about carers or family members
changes in mood, such as frequent mood swings, depression and feeling increasingly anxious, frustrated or agitated
response: You may have alzheimers. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: pain in the lower right side of your abdomen
pain that starts near your belly button and moves to the lower right side of your abdomen
pain that gets worse when you cough or move
response: You may have appendicitis. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: atopic eczema causes areas of skin to become itchy, dry, cracked, sore and red

atopic eczema can occur all over the body, but is most common on the hands (especially fingers), the insides of the elbows or backs of the knees, and the face and scalp in children. the face is more commonly involved in adults
people with mild eczema may only have small areas of dry skin that are occasionally itchy
widespread red, inflamed skin all over the body and constant itching
response: You may have atopic eczema. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: having a short attention span and being easily distracted
making careless mistakes – for example, in schoolwork
being unable to stick at tasks that are tedious or time-consuming
appearing to be unable to listen to or carry out instructions
being unable to wait their turn
response: You may have attencion deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd). Please see a doctor.

symptoms: symptom is a spotty, blistering red rash that can cover the entire body
The spots normally appear in clusters and tend to be in behind the ears, on the face, over the scalp, on the chest and belly, on the arm and the legs
although the rash starts as small, itchy red spots, these develop a blister on top and become intensely itchy after about 12-14 hours
response: You may have chickenpox. Please see a doctor.

symptoms: a rash on skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes
a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste
response: You may have Corona Virus. Please see a doctor.
